analysis_funcs module¶

An implementation of statistical analysis in the supplementary material of [arXiv]

This is a Python implementation of the two-step model used in the supplementary information of the paper “High-fidelity indirect readout of trapped-ion hyperfine qubits”. We refer to that document for details.

arXiv

arXiv xxxx.xxxxx

analysis_funcs.bare(point, i)[source]¶

The “bare” measurement error.

This is the lowest order estimate of the measurement infidelity, given by \(\hat{r}(\neg i, i|i)\).

Literally returns return point[not_i(i), i, i]

analysis_funcs.bare_at_lower(data, alpha, i)[source]¶

The lowest order measurement infidelity at the confidence lower bound.

Similar to

See also

bare_at_upper()

analysis_funcs.bare_at_upper(data, alpha, i)[source]¶

The lowest order measurement infidelity at the confidence upper bound.

See also

bare()

Parameters

  • data – Counts to compute for.

  • alpha – Significance level

  • i – Indended prep

Returns

Literally returns return bare(upper_from_data(data, alpha), i)

analysis_funcs.data_to_point(data)[source]¶

From a set of data \(n\), returns the corresponding \(\hat{r}\).

This implements equation S.20.

Parameters

data – Counts.

Returns

The frequencies corresponding to the counts.

Computes the Clopper-Pearson confidence lower bounds from the data.

The returned array is of the same shape as the input.

clopper_lower()

Parameters

  • alpha – The significance level to compute the lower bounds at.

analysis_funcs.lower_reference_point(r, c, i)[source]¶

This is \(f(r, c, x) \equiv r(\neg x, x|x) - l(r,c,x)\)

See also

upper_reference_point()

analysis_funcs.lowerb(r, c, i)[source]¶

Computes an upper bound to the higher order corrections for the estimate of infidelity.

Equation S.18 in the supplement.

Parameters

  • r – The frequencies to compute the upper bound for.

  • c – The parameter used to bound the infidelities.

  • i – Initial prep.

Returns

\(l(r, c, i)\)

analysis_funcs.not_i(i)[source]¶

return (i+1)%2

analysis_funcs.optimal_lower_beta(data, alpha, c, i)[source]¶

Given data and a fixed total significance, finds the optimal significance to assign to the higher order corrections.

Optimal in the sense of giving the tightest lower bound.

See also

optimal_upper_beta()

analysis_funcs.optimal_upper_beta(data, alpha, c, i)[source]¶

Given data and a fixed total significance, finds the optimal significance to assign to the higher order corrections.

Optimal in the sense of giving the tightest upper bound.

Note that this is a function exclusively used before the true data is seen, only used to find a good choice for \(\beta\) . Using this function after the data is seen is cheating, and does not give a legitimate confidence interval.

This is equation S.24

Uses scipy.optimize.minimize_scalar.

Parameters

  • data – Training data to compute confidence upper bound for.

  • alpha – Significance level.

  • c – \(c\)

  • i – Intended preparation.

Returns

\(\beta^*(n, \alpha, c, i)\)

analysis_funcs.point_at_nominal(nominal_meas, nominal_prep, other_meas=None, i=0)[source]¶

From a pair of “nominal” measurement and state prep errors, makes a distribution described by those errors.

For a “nominal measurement error” \(e_m\) and a “nominal preparation error” \(e_p\), this function prepares the distribution

\[\begin{split}r(\neg i, \neg i|i) &= e_p \\ r(i, i, |\neg i) &= e_p \\ r(\neg i, i|i) &= e_m \\ r(i, \neg i|i) &= e_m \\ r(i,\neg i|\neg i) &= e_m \\ r(\neg i,i|\neg i) &= e_m \\\end{split}\]

and the other two components of the probability distribution such that the appropriate normalization constraints are satisfied. If other_meas is specified, \(r(i,\neg i|\neg i)\) and \(r(\neg i,i|\neg i)\) are set to that instead.

Parameters

  • nominal_meas (float) – Should be larger than 0, less than 1.

  • other_meas – Defaults to nominal_meas

Returns

A probability distribution, with axes such that point_at_nominal(a, b)[x, y, z] = r(x, y|z)

analysis_funcs.point_to_data(n0, n1, point)[source]¶

From a pair of “total number of experiments in prep 0”, “total number of experiments in prep 1” and a point \(r\), returns counts that round to the given \(r\).

The rounding is such that the total numbers \(N_i\) are preserved. This is done by subtracting any discrepancy from \(n(i, i, i)\).

Parameters

  • n0 – Total number of experiments with prep 0. This quantity is \(N_0\) in the supplement.

  • n1 – Total number of experiments with prep 1. This quantity is \(N_1\) in the supplement.

  • point – The point \(r\) to create data from.

Returns

Counts. Indexed in the same way that point is, namely:

point_to_data(n0, n1, point)[x, y, z] = n(x, y, z)

where n in the above refers to the \(n\) in the supplement.

analysis_funcs.total_lower(data, alpha, beta, c, i)[source]¶

The confidence lower bound for the measurement infidelity.

If we obtain something negative from subtracting off the higher order corrections, we return 0.

See also

total_upper()

analysis_funcs.total_upper(data, alpha, beta, c, i)[source]¶

The confidence upper bound for the measurement infidelity.

Computed using the union bound. This is Equation S.21 in the supplement for \(\gamma = 3\beta\).

Parameters

  • data – The counts to compute for.

  • alpha – Total significance level.

  • beta – The significance to “give to” the higher order terms.

  • c – \(c\), the coarse lower bound on all the fidelities.

  • i – Intended prep

Returns

The upper bounds.

analysis_funcs.upper_from_data(data, alpha)[source]¶

Computes the Clopper-Pearson confidence upper bounds from the data.

The returned array is of the same shape as the input.

See also

clopper_upper()

Parameters

  • data – \(n(x, y, z)\) in the supplement.

  • alpha – The significance level to compute the upper bounds at.

Returns

\(\overline{r(x, y|z)}(\alpha, n)\)

analysis_funcs.upper_loss(data, alpha, beta, c, i)[source]¶

A loss function to analyze quality of the choice for \(\beta\).

Equation S.25.

Note that this function is only used for training purposes, we use this only on artificial training counts.

Parameters

  • data – The data to compute for.

  • alpha – The total significance.

  • beta – Significance for the higher order terms.

  • c – \(c\)

  • i – Intended preparation.

Returns

\(d(\beta, n, \alpha, c, i)\)

analysis_funcs.upper_reference_point(r, c, i)[source]¶

This is \(g(r, c, x) \equiv r(\neg x, x|x) + u(r,c,x)\)

Parameters

  • r – \(r\)

  • c – \(c\)

  • i – Intended prep.

Returns

\(f\)

analysis_funcs.upperb(r, c, i)[source]¶

Computes an upper bound to the higher order corrections for the estimate of infidelity.

Equation S.16 in the supplement.

Parameters

  • r – The frequencies to compute the upper bound for.

  • c – The parameter used to bound the infidelities.

  • i – Initial prep.

Returns

\(u(r, c, i)\)

analysis_funcs.upperb_at_upper(data, alpha, c, i)[source]¶

Computes \(u(\overline{r}(\alpha, n), c, x)\).

This is used in Equation S.22

Parameters

  • data – \(n\)

  • alpha – The significance level to compute the confidence upper bound at.

  • c – \(c\)

  • i – Intended preparation.

Returns

The upper bounds return upperb(upper_from_data(data, alpha), c, i)
